Note: Cf. 5390, lines 21-29, to which this generally corresponds.
_description: A verse introduction to a prose medical text — varying lines, generally in couplets

CamEmm95.Transcription:
This boke hiȝte ypocrason of the beste surgeons þat euer
                    was& galien his felawe & socratesto þem þis booke
                    beryn witnesefor all þey weryn felawes in ferewhile þey
                    lefde in erþe hereand þorough þe grace of hevyne
                    kyngþey practiseden medecynes to helpyn [ ]praye we al to ihesu
                    hevyne kynghe yif here soule gode wonyng
CamEmm95.Note:
Followed by ‘Iste liber Johanni Chaucis & cetera
                        Constat’ (p. 120).

BLSl468.Transcription:
þis boke hyȝte ypocrasOon þe best surgyen þat
                    euer was& galien his felow & socratesTo þis bok bere
                    witnesfor alle þey were felowes in ferewhil þey leueden in
                    erthe here& þorw þe grace of heuene kyngeÞe[i]
                    practised medicynes to help mankendePrey we alle to ihu heuene kyngGod
                    ȝeue here soules good wonyngAmen

BLHar1735.First Lines: þis bok heyght ypocrasþe best surgyon þat heuer In þis world was…
BLHar1735.Last Lines: …þoro grace of heue kyngþey halp many men with hare lechyng
BLHar1735.Note: Stands alone, not as an introduction or epilogue.
